t: John 21
Jesus and the Miraculous Catch of Fish
Afterward*p Jesus appeared again to his disciples, by the Sea of Galilee. It happened this way:
Simon Peter, Thomas (also known as Didymus), Nathanael from Cana in Galilee, the sons of Zebedee, and two other disciples were together.
“I’m going out to fish,” Simon Peter told them, and they said, “We’ll go with you.” So they went out and got into the boat, but that night they caught nothing.
Early*p in the morning, Jesus stood on the shore, but the disciples did not realize that it was Jesus.
He*p called out to them, “Friends,*r haven’t*r you*r any*r fish?”*r “No,”*p they answered.
He*p said, “Throw*r your*r net*r on*r the*r right*r side*r of*r the*r boat*r and*r you*r will*r find*r some.”*r When they did, they were unable to haul the net in because of the large number of fish.

Then*p the disciple whom Jesus loved said to Peter, “It is the Lord!” As soon as Simon Peter heard him say, “It is the Lord,” he wrapped his outer garment around him (for he had taken it off) and jumped into the water.
The other disciples followed in the boat, towing the net full of fish, for they were not far from shore, about a hundred yards.
When they landed, they saw a fire of burning coals there with fish on it, and some bread.
Jesus*p said to them, “Bring*r some*r of*r the*r fish*r you*r have*r just*r caught.”*r
So Simon Peter climbed back into the boat and dragged the net ashore. It was full of large fish, 153, but even with so many the net was not torn.
Jesus said to them, “Come*r and*r have*r breakfast.”*r None of the disciples dared ask him, “Who are you?” They knew it was the Lord.
Jesus came, took the bread and gave it to them, and did the same with the fish.
This was now the third time Jesus appeared to his disciples after he was raised from the dead.
Jesus Reinstates Peter

When*p they had finished eating, Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon*r son*r of*r John,*r do*r you*r love*r me*r more*r than*r these?”*r “Yes,*p Lord,” he said, “you know that I love you.” Jesus*p said, “Feed*r my*r lambs.”*r
Again*p Jesus said, “Simon*r son*r of*r John,*r do*r you*r love*r me?”*r He*p answered, “Yes, Lord, you know that I love you.” Jesus*p said, “Take*r care*r of*r my*r sheep.”*r

The*p third time he said to him, “Simon*r son*r of*r John,*r do*r you*r love*r me?”*r Peter*p was hurt because Jesus asked him the third time, “Do*r you*r love*r me?”*r He said, “Lord, you know all things; you know that I love you.” Jesus*p said, “Feed*r my*r sheep.*r

Very*r truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r when*r you*r were*r younger*r you*r dressed*r yourself*r and*r went*r where*r you*r wanted;*r but*r when*r you*r are*r old*r you*r will*r stretch*r out*r your*r hands,*r and*r someone*r else*r will*r dress*r you*r and*r lead*r you*r where*r you*r do*r not*r want*r to*r go.”*r
Jesus said this to indicate the kind of death by which Peter would glorify God. Then he said to him, “Follow*r me!”*r
Peter*p turned and saw that the disciple whom Jesus loved was following them. (This was the one who had leaned back against Jesus at the supper and had said, “Lord, who is going to betray you?”)
When Peter saw him, he asked, “Lord, what about him?”
Jesus*p answered, “If*r I*r want*r him*r to*r remain*r alive*r until*r I*r return,*r what*r is*r that*r to*r you?*r You*r must*r follow*r me.”*r

Because of this, the rumor spread among the believers that this disciple would not die. But Jesus did not say that he would not die; he only said, “If*r I*r want*r him*r to*r remain*r alive*r until*r I*r return,*r what*r is*r that*r to*r you?”*r
This*p is the disciple who testifies to these things and who wrote them down. We know that his testimony is true.
Jesus*p did many other things as well. If every one of them were written down, I suppose that even the whole world would not have room for the books that would be written.
